revision.text:
'''Allen Raymond''' is a former [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Political consulting|political consultant]] in the [[United States]] who spent three months in federal prison for his role in the [[2002 New Hampshire Senate election phone jamming scandal]], for which he was convicted of making harassing phone calls across state lines, a felony.<ref name=kranish>[http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2006/06/10/fallen_star_blames_self_gop_tactics/ "Fallen star blames self, GOP tactics: Jail term served in N.H. phone plot"] By Michael Kranish, ''[[Boston Globe]]'' June 10, 2006.</ref> Raymond is the author of the book, ''How to Rig an Election: Confessions of a Republican Operative'' (2008).
==Phone jamming scandal== {{see also|2002 New Hampshire Senate election phone jamming scandal}} Raymond told investigators that his former [[Republican National Committee]] colleague [[James Tobin (political operative)|James Tobin]] approached him with a plan to tie up the phones of New Hampshire Democrats on [[Election Day (politics)|Election Day]] 2002, during a close Senate race between Republican [[John E. Sununu]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Jeanne Shaheen]]. At the time, Raymond owned a Virginia-based GOP phone-bank company ([[GOP Marketplace]]) and also held a paid position as Executive Director of the [[Republican Leadership Council]].
Raymond then collected $15,600 from the New Hampshire Republican State Committee and paid a small Idaho telemarketing company $2,300 to make non-stop hangup phone calls to six New Hampshire phone lines, five of which were being used by the Democratic Party to get out the vote. The sixth phone line belonged to the [[Manchester, New Hampshire|Manchester]] Firefighters' Union, which offers free rides to the polls.
In an interview with the ''[[Boston Globe]]'', Raymond said he took part in the phone-jamming because he "had been reluctant to turn down a prominent official of the RNC, fearing that would cost him future opportunities from an organization that was becoming increasingly ruthless."<ref name=kranish/>
==''How to Rig an Election''==
The closing paragraph of his book ''[[How to Rig an Election]]: Confessions of a Republican Operative'' ends with a line that reflects on a conversation with his wife just before he entered jail; "After ten full years inside the GOP, ninety days amongst honest criminals wasn't any great ordeal."<ref>''How to Rig an Election: Confessions of a Republican Operative'' ({{ISBN|1-4165-5222-7}})</ref>
==Media appearances== * Appeared on ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' on October 24, 2008, talking about his book * Appeared on ''The Daily Show'' January 17, 2008 * Appeared on ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show (TV series)|The Rachel Maddow Show]]'' on January 27, 2009
==Books== * ''[[How to Rig an Election]]: Confessions of a Republican Operative'' ({{ISBN|1-4165-5222-7}}).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite journal | first = Jim| last = Acosta |author2=Ronni Berke | date = October 22, 2008 | title =Ex-GOP operative tells cautionary tale about 'how to rig an election' | journal =CNN | url =http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/10/22/rigging.election/ }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20030402164948/http://www.politicsnj.com/kornacki021003_Raymond.htm February 10. 2003 ''PoliticsNJ.com'' "Consultant with NJ ties implicated as NH campaign trickster"] * [http://www.democracynow.org/2008/1/8/how_to_rig_an_election_convicted January 08, 2008 ''Democracy Now!'' "How to Rig an Election: Convicted Former GOP Operative Details 2002 New Hampshire Phone Jamming Scheme"] * [http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/01/15/how-to-rig-an-election-ask-the-author/ January 15, 2008 Raymond answers readers' questions at "Freakonomics blog"] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vlR1a_oQSOQ Allen Raymond interviewed by Velvet Revolution, January 2008] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AKz0rfLaf0Y Allen Raymond interviewed by Regal Literary, April 2008]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Raymond, Allen}} [[Category:American political consultants]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New Hampshire Republicans]] [[Category:American criminals]] [[Category:New Hampshire politicians convicted of crimes]]

revision.text:
{{Missing information|prohibition of cannabis in Guatemala|date=November 2017}} '''Cannabis in Guatemala''', as of 2016, is illegal. [[Otto Pérez Molina|Otto Pérez]], when he was president of the country, tried to lead a legalization drive, and some congressmen tried to pass a law for legalization, but those efforts failed. A poll conducted in 2012 said that 41% of Guatemalans might support decriminalization.
==History== One early law restricting cannabis was Decree 1331 of 1932, which restricted "plantas letales" to include "Indian hemp and marihuana".<ref name="Policía1935">{{cite book|author=Guatemala. Dirección General de Policía|title=Memoria de los trabajos realizados por la Dirección General de la Policía Nacional durante el año de ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_hWAAAAYAAJ|year=1935|publisher=Tipografía Nacional|page=123}}</ref>
In 2012, former Guatemalan president Otto Pérez announced his support for decriminalizing drugs, but he said that the United States boycotted his plans. He nevertheless tried to promote the idea in diverse forums, culminating in a speech he gave before the United Nations General Assembly in New York on 26 September 2012. A poll in that year revealed that 41% of Guatemalans thought that decriminalization was a good idea.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/plan-de-legalizar-droga-coincidio-con-conexion-z|title=Plan de legalizar droga coincidió con conexión Z|last=Ramos|first=Gerson|last2=Álvarez|first2=Carlos|date=June 10, 2017|website=Prensa Libre|archive-url=https://archive.today/20171106182818/http://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/plan-de-legalizar-droga-coincidio-con-conexion-z#|archive-date=2017-11-06|dead-url=no|access-date=6 Nov 2017|df=}}</ref>
In 2016 the Commission of legislation and constitutional points of Congress (Spanish: Comisión de Legislación y Puntos Constitucionales del Congreso) in Guatemala rejected the ''Law to regulate the cultivation, production, distribution, commercialization, medicinal and recreational consumption of cannabis'' (Spanish: ''Ley para Regular el Cultivo, Producción, Distribución, Comercialización y Consumo Medicinal y Recreativo del Cannabis)'' as "unfeasible, inopportune, and unconstitutional". The law had been proposed in April of that year by the congressmen from the party Convergencia. [[Alvaro Velázquez]], one of the congressmen, had said he would keep trying for the initiative to advance <ref>{{cite web|author=Milena Lopez |url=http://www.tn8.tv/cronica-tn8/373406-comision-rechaza-uso-medicinal-marihuana-guatemala/ |title=Comisión Rechaza Uso Medicinal De La Marihuana En Guatemala |publisher=Tn8.tv |date= |accessdate=2016-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Juan Toro |url=http://clustersalud.americaeconomia.com/guatemala-rechazan-uso-marihuana-medicinal/ |title=Guatemala: Rechazan uso de marihuana medicinal - Cluster Salud, La Industria de la vida |publisher=Clustersalud.americaeconomia.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-30}}</ref> but he died in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/justicia/localizan-cadaver-del-diputado-alvaro-velasquez-en-la-casa-donde-habitaba-en-mixco|title=Localizan cadáver del diputado Álvaro Velásquez en una casa, en Mixco|last=Bolaños|first=Rosa|last2=Gamarro|first2=Urias|date=July 29, 2017|website=Prensa Libre|archive-url=https://archive.today/20171106062406/http://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/justicia/localizan-cadaver-del-diputado-alvaro-velasquez-en-la-casa-donde-habitaba-en-mixco#|archive-date=2017-11-06|dead-url=no|access-date=Nov 6, 2017|df=}}</ref>
== Conviction and sentences == According to Guatemalan law, cannabis is illegal, as of 2016, and a person convicted of personal consumption of a drug (including cannabis) would be sentenced to a minimum of 4 months in jail and a 200 quetzals fine, and up to 5 years and a 10,000 quetzals fine, but because "personal consumption" is not defined properly, the prosecutor can accuse the person of traffic and the judge may give a sentence of up to 20 years in prison.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tni.org/es/publicacion/reforma-de-la-ley-de-drogas-en-guatemala-guia-basica#1|title=Reforma de la ley de drogas en Guatemala: guía básica|last=|first=|date=30 July 2015|website=tni|archive-url=https://archive.today/20171107083022/https://www.tni.org/es/publicacion/reforma-de-la-ley-de-drogas-en-guatemala-guia-basica%231#1#1|archive-date=2017-11-07|dead-url=no|access-date=7 Nov 2017|df=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== See also == * [[Cannabis (drug)|Cannabis]] * [[Effects of cannabis]] * [[Legality of cannabis]] * [[Medical cannabis]] * [[Drug prohibition]] * [[Drug liberalization]]
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-A7wSu-weio Video of speech of former Guatemalan president Otto Pérez before the United Nations General Assembly in 2012] (in Spanish)
{{portalbar|Cannabis|Guatemala}} {{Americas topic|Cannabis in}} {{Cannabis by country}}

revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=July 2017}} A '''chuckmuck''' is a belt-hung leather and metal tinder pouch. It is a distinct design of a flint-and-steel fire-lighting kit. It is also used as ethnic jewellery amongst Tibetans and Mongolians.
==Description== The chuckmuck is constructed from a stiff leather purse with a thick curved steel striker attached by rivets to its base. The sides and flap of the purse are either sewn or fixed by ornamental metal plates or small plaques. Inside are kept a piece of flint and a little tinder (pulped woody material such as plant roots). On the top fold a thin metal plate with 1 - 3 small hooks allows the pouch to be hung from the belt with a chuckmuck strap: a chain, leather thong or embroidered cloth.
Chuckmucks vary in size and decoration, with the circular boss in the centre of the flap, which operates as a hook to keep the purse closed, sometimes being decorated by a semi-precious stone such as coral or turquoise. Other decorations on the mounts are in silver, brass or iron with geometric patterns, floral designs, Tibetan motifs, or in the [[animal style]].<ref>J.N.Roerich 1930 'the animal style among the nomad tribes of Northern Tibet'</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianart.com/articles/thogchags/|title=John Vincent Bellezza: Thogchags, Ancient Amulets of Tibet|work=asianart.com}}</ref> The steel striker is occasionally engraved: with two dragons<ref>{{cite web|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O89544/tinder-pouch-unknown/ |title=Tinder pouch | V&A Search the Collections |publisher=Collections.vam.ac.uk |date=2015-08-10 |accessdate=2015-08-15}}</ref> or [[Chinese characters]]. The [[University of Washington]] database contains a collection of fire steels including early chuckmucks on plates 45-48 from several countries.<ref name=abr>{{cite web |url=http://www.arl.wustl.edu/~mlw2/tmp/steel/plates |title=Steel plate images |publisher=Arl.wustl.edu |accessdate=2015-08-15 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The chuckmuck is hung from the belt in both Mongolian and Tibetan traditional dress for men and women. For this reason it is sometimes described as a [[Chatelaine (chain)]] with strap ornaments, as in the [[British Museum]] exhibit.<ref name=brx>{{cite web|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?museumno=1924,0620.12.a|title=British Museum - Collection search: You searched for|work=British Museum}}</ref> It is sometimes accompanied by a 'chuckmuck purse' as a jewellery set<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pinterest.com/stoneroutes/|title=Bradley Rowe|work=Pinterest}}</ref> in exactly the same style only lacking the curved steel striker.
==History== The container for a [[fire striker|flint-and-steel]] kit can come in two main forms: the tinderbox<ref name=br1>{{cite web|url=http://www.colonialsense.com/Antiques/Other_Antiques/Early_Lighting/The_Common_Tinder-Box.php|title=Colonial Sense: Antiques: Other Antiques: Early Lighting: The Common Tinder-Box|work=colonialsense.com}}</ref> and the tinder pouch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prm.ox.ac.uk/fire.html|title=Methods of Making Fire - Pitt Rivers Museum|author=Pitt Rivers Museum|work=ox.ac.uk}}</ref> A fire lighting kit for 'striking a light' was essential until the gradual introduction of the [[match]] in the mid 19th century. The form of the chuckmuck is so different from other tinder pouches worldwide that categorising them together is misleading.{{or|date=August 2015}} The decorated stiff leather purse of the chuckmuck with its attached curved striker make it a design classic.{{peacock term|date=August 2015}}
The chuckmuck design appears in many cultures from the 17th century<ref name="abr"/> or earlier, stretching from the [[Silk Road]] to the [[Himalaya]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=As1983,07.115.a|title=British Museum - Collection search: You searched for As1983,07.115.a|work=British Museum}}</ref> and China<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=As1878,1230.956|title=British Museum - Collection search: You searched for As1878,1230.956|work=British Museum}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=As1911,1007.1|title=British Museum - Collection search: You searched for As1911,1007.1|work=British Museum}}</ref> to Japan<ref name=aby>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/21861/lot/109/|title=Bonhams|work=bonhams.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.batemans.com/lot.php?lot=124695|title=Batemans|work=Batemans}}</ref>
It is not known where or when the design originated, but it was manufactured locally in several countries in Central Asia.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} One known, still active, hub of metalwork was the area between Lanzhou, Xining and [[Labrang]], the NE part of [[Amdo]] which incorporates the Amdo Tibetans, some Mongol regions, the [[Salar people|Salar]], the [[Hui people|Hui]] and Han Chinese. In Tibet, apart from Lhasa and a very few other towns, only [[Derge]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/8271811/Recent_Acquisitions_of_Tibetan_and_Mongolian_Arms_and_Armor_in_the_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_part_2_|title=Recent Acquisitions of Tibetan and Mongolian Arms and Armor in the Metropolitan Museum of Art (part 2)|author=Donald LaRocca|work=academia.edu}}</ref> was renowned for the quality of its metalwork.
The 19th-century growth in museums and world expositions in several countries led to many exhibits on the theme of man making fire and several of these included examples of chuckmucks. As a result, many museums and old collections contain chuckmucks; they occasionally appear in antique auctions.<ref>National Museum of Scotland Museum reference A.1927.661</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/a-brass-mounted-tinder-pouch-or-chuckmuck-chinese-4631465-details.aspx?pos=7&intObjectID=4631465&sid=&page=8&lid=1|title=A brass-mounted tinder pouch or "chuckmuck"|author=Christie?s|work=christies.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/21835/lot/14/|title=Bonhams|work=bonhams.com}}</ref>
In 1926 a British museum of Fire-Making Appliances catalogued 52 of these chuckmucks and illustrated 11. "Of all tinder-pouches, by far the handsomest and most interesting are those commonly known by this name, which form an exceeding well-marked group. All come from one part of the world covering Tibet, the Himalayan region, Mongolia and Northern China." <ref>The Bryant and May Museum of Fire-Making appliances: catalogue of the exhibits" London 1926 (and supplement 1928) pages 66-73 and 221</ref> The whole museum collection was transferred to [[the Science Museum]] in 1937 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/about_us/collections/about_the_collections/collections_snapshot/bryant_and_may_collection.aspx |title=The Bryant & May collection of fire-lighting devices - About us |publisher=Science Museum |date=2007-02-12 |accessdate=2015-08-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/info.php?s=chuckmuck&type=all&t=objects |title=Chuckmuck images |publisher=Collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk |accessdate=2015-08-15}}</ref>
Museums worldwide today classify them in a variety of different ways: "pouch (tinder flint)"<ref name=brx /> "tinder pouch ('mecha')'<ref name="abr" /> fire-striker, flint-steel set etc and rarely mention the chuckmuck design to distinguish it from other pouches.
==Etymology== [[File:Chuckmuck straps- mechag style (Tibet)- cloth and leather belt straps for suspending chuckmucks photo Stone Routes.JPG|thumb|Mechag style cloth and leather belt straps for suspending chuckmucks]] Chuckmuck is derived via the British Indian word ''chakmak'' <ref>Ivor Lewis 1991 Sahibs, nabobs and boxwallahs: a dictionary of the words of Anglo-India</ref> from the [[Turkish language|Turkish]] word for flint, ''çakmaktaşı''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tureng.com/search/flint|title=Tureng - flint - Turkish English Dictionary|work=tureng.com}}</ref> This word of Turkic origin was simplified and incorporated as slang in many languages of Central Asia. When encountered in British India during contact with Himalayan Tibetan tribes, it became identified as a particular form of fire-steel - the chuckmuck. Since this coincided with the introduction of the friction [[match]], the function of the [[tinderbox]] and tinder pouch gradually became unnecessary, and by the end of the 19th century, only its use as ethnic jewellery by Mongolians and Tibetans kept the chuckmuck in daily use.
===Chuckmuck=== For a few decades in mid 19th century, ''chuckmuck'' and ''chakmak'' were used almost interchangeably as the ‘Indian’ word for any type of fire-steel.
The first known use of the word ''chuckmuck'' comes from 1843 from British India: ''“the coolness of the British soldier is shewn by his sitting down and lighting his chuckmuck and enjoying the solace of his pipe while the arrows of death were bustling around his ears”''.<ref>Smith, Elder, and Company, 1843 The British Friend of India Magazine, and Indian Review</ref>
In central India, north west of Mumbai, a British officer <ref>Henry Astbury Leveson 1860 The hunting grounds of the Old world, by 'The old shekarry'</ref> describes a local guide: ''“Round his waist was a broad leather belt, hung round with numerous pouches…and a chuckmuck, or leather bag, with flint, steel and tinder.”'' This would best be described as a tinder pouch, and, that of the pipe smoking soldiers a simple metal tube with striker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://southpadretv.tv/making-sparks-a-brief-history-of-firemaking-1640|title=Making Sparks a Brief History of Firemaking|work=southpadretv.tv}}</ref>
A camping book in 1871 details ''"a very convenient and portable means of carrying fire, sold under the name of "strike-a-light" or "chuckmuck"; it is formed of a brass tube of 1in. caliber and 3in. in length, which has a cap and a sliding bottom to it : it is filled of tinder….it contains also a gun flint or bit of agate, and its chain passes through an oval of steel or case-hardened iron”'' costing around a shilling <ref>W.B. Lord & T. Baines 1871 Shifts and expedients of camp life, travel & exploration</ref> - clearly one of the plethora of short-lived metal tinderbox designs.
However, after the 1889 publication of Hindu-koh<ref>Donald Macintyre 1889 Hindu-Koh: Wanderings and Wild Sport on and Beyond the Himalayas</ref> by Donald Macintyre (VC), a prominent British Gurkha officer, containing the first known illustration and description of a chuckmuck, the word became more strictly defined in academic circles. Macintyre actually made his hunting trip, on which the book is based, in the Himalaya in 1853-4, and was a prominent fellow of the Royal Geographical Society and other Indian societies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Macintyre,_Donald_(DNB12)|title=Macintyre, Donald (DNB12)|work=wikisource.org}}</ref>
The museum categorisation of ''chuckmuck'' dates from this time. After that, all academic descriptions, where they were catalogued in English, used the word to refer to the classic design of the chuckmuck. ''Chakmak'' does not appear to have been used as a descriptive term outside India.<ref>A.J.Cruse 1946 Match-box Labels of the World: With a History of Fire-making Appliances from Primitive Man to the Modern Match</ref>
''Chuckmuck'' was defined as an Anglo-Indian word.<ref>Sir Henry Yule 1903 Anglo-English Words and Phrases.</ref> It continues to be used in books in English about the history of fire-lighting.<ref>Ad Van Weert Dutch Lighter Museum 1995 The Legend of the Lighter</ref>
===Chakmak=== Catholic missionaries had a presence in Western Tibet from 1624 to 1640. The initial reports of the Jesuit [[António de Andrade]], including dictionaries, were supplemented by many others in the 19th century on the eastern fringes of the Tibetan plateau, leading to an 1899 dictionary<ref>Société des Missions Étrangères, 1899. Les Missionaire Catholiques du Thibet: Dictionnaire Tibétain-Latin-Français</ref> citing ''lcags ma'' and ''lcags mag'', pronounced as ''chagmag'',<ref>[[Sándor Kőrösi Csoma|Alexander Csoma de Koros]] 1834 A Dictionary of Tibetan and English</ref> as vulgar slang for ''me lcags'', itself often transliterated as ''mechag''.<ref>Thubten Jigme Norbu, Colin Turnbull 1968 Tibet</ref>
In Nepal, a traditional [[kukri]] features two little knives attached at the back of the sheath. One is called a ''chakmak''. It is blunt on both sides and it works like a knife sharpener or when struck on a lime stone creates sparks to start fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khukuriblades.com/kukri_history/|title=Kukri history:: Khukuri history:: Khukri history:: Origin of Gurkha knife/kukri|work=khukuriblades.com}}</ref>
''Chakmak'', as an Indian word, was widely used in reports and books in British India. ''“In Ladakh both men and women wore in their waste-clothes or girdles a chakmak (or leather case ornamented with brass, containing a flint, steel and tinder)”''.<ref>Raj Kumar 2006. Paintings and lifestyles of Jammu Region : from 17th to 19th century A.D.</ref>
[[William Moorcroft (explorer)|William Moorcroft]], extensively catalogued the Himalayan regions around Ladakh in the 1820s, noting ''“Every man carries a knife hanging from his girdle, and a chakmak,or steel for striking a light”''. As he was describing Tibetan dress, these were of the classic chuckmuck design.<ref>William Moorcroft 1841 Travels in the Himalayan Provinces of Hindustan From 1819 to 1825</ref>
In 1891 [[William Woodville Rockhill]] recorded some of [[Salar language]], an archaic Turkic dialect spoken near Lanzhou between the Tibetan plateau and Mongolia. He derived the Salar word ''cha’-ma'' from [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] ''chakmak''.<ref>WW Rockhill 1894 Diary of a journey through Mongolia and Tibet</ref> Similarly, in [[Uyghur language]], a Turkic language spoken in western China, the word for flint is ''chaqmaq teshi''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uighurdictionary.com/?s=flint|title=flint - Search Results - English Uyghur Dictionary|work=uighurdictionary.com}}</ref>
In Persian and Arabic, ''chakmak'' means "flint" or "fire-striker".<ref>John Richardson 1829 A Dictionary, Persian, Arabic, and English</ref> An early example dated 1716 is from Persia, where the Islamic inscription reads ''“The fire steel (''chakmak'') of his heart is so filled with sparks that his charged sight intensifies the burning”'' <ref>[http://www.arl.wustl.edu/~mlw2/tmp/steel/catalogue.pdf plate 35.201]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In the [[Kyrgyz language]], as noted by an 1899 Danish expedition, the ''"apparatus for striking fire is called Chakmak. It is possible that flint is found by this lake of Chakmaktinkul and that the name may arise therefrom in relation to the striking of fire from flint"''.<ref>the Second Danish Pamir Expedition 1898-99 Through the Unknown Pamirs</ref>
===In other languages=== *In Mongolian, ''kete''<ref>F D Lessing 2014 Mongolian-English Dictionary</ref> *In Japanese, ''hiuchi-bukuro'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://loringpage.com/kiseruarticle/jp7.htm|title=Japanese Pipe & Accessories 7 (netsuke)|work=loringpage.com}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Firelighting}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} This article is about the [[demographics|demographic]] features of the [[population]] of [[Senegal]], including [[population density]], [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]], education level, health of the populace, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the population. About 42% of [[Senegal]]'s population is rural. In rural areas, population density varies from about 77 per square kilometer (200/mile²) in the west-central region to 2 per square kilometer (5/mile²) in the arid eastern section. The average population density for the country is 68 people per square kilometer (169/sq mi). French is the official language but is used regularly only by the literate minority. Almost all Senegalese speak an indigenous language, of which [[Wolof language|Wolof]] has the largest usage. Many Senegalese live in Europe, particularly in France, Italy and Spain. ==Population== [[Image:Senegal population.svg|thumb|right|Demographics of Senegal, From UN estimates; Number of inhabitants in millions.]] According to the 2018 revision of the World Population Review{{cite |url=http://worldpopulationreview.com/countries/senegal-population/ |title=World Population Review: Senegal Population 2018|date=14 June 2018 }} the total population was 16,302,789 in May 2018, compared to only 2,416,000 in 1950. The proportion of children below the age of 15 in 2017 was 41.5%, between 15 and 54 years of age was 31.1%, while 55 years or older was 6.9%. .[http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/index.htm Population Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the United Nations Secretariat, World Population Prospects: The 2010 Revision] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506000000/http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/index.htm |date=6 May 2011 }} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: right;" |- ! ! width="80pt"|Total population ! width="80pt"|Population aged 0–14 (%) ! width="80pt"|Population aged 15–64 (%) ! width="80pt"|Population aged 65+ (%) |- | 1950 |2,416,000||41.6||55.0||3.4 |- | 1955 |2,684,000||41.5||55.6||2.9 |- | 1960 |3,048,000||41.9||55.5||2.6 |- | 1965 |3,505,000||43.0||54.6||2.4 |- | 1970 |4,096,000||44.3||53.5||2.3 |- | 1975 |4,786,000||45.3||52.5||2.2 |- | 1980 |5,414,000||47.2||50.5||2.2 |- | 1985 |6,232,000||47.7||50.0||2.3 |- | 1990 |7,242,000||47.2||50.4||2.4 |- | 1995 |8,369,000||46.2||51.3||2.5 |- | 2000 |9,506,000||45.4||52.1||2.5 |- | 2005 |10,872,000||44.4||53.1||2.5 |- | 2010 |12,434,000||43.7||53.9||2.4 |- | 2017 |14,668,522||41.5||55.5||2.9 |} ==Vital statistics== Registration of vital events in Senegal is not complete. align="left" | Total ! colspan="2" | 4,879,103 ! colspan="2" | 6,773,417 |} ==Languages== {{main|Languages of Senegal}} [[French language|French]] (official), [[Wolof language|Wolof]], [[Pulaar language|Pulaar]], [[Serer language|Serer]], [[Jola language|Jola]], [[Mandinka language|Mandinka]], [[Soninke language|Soninke]] ==Religion== {{main|Religion in Senegal}} The religion beliefs of the 2016 population of Senegal are: [[Muslim]] 96.1% (mostly Sufi), [[Christian]] 3.6% (mostly Roman Catholic), [[animist]] 0.3%. == Other general statistics == The following demographic statistics of Senegal are from the World Population Review. *One birth every 57 seconds *One death every 6 minutes *Net gain of one person every 1 minutes *One net migrant every 26 minutes *About 43% of the population lives below the national poverty line. The following demographic statistics are from the [[CIA World Factbook]], unless otherwise indicated.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/sg.html|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov}} ===Life expectancy at birth=== :Total population: 62.1 years (2017 est.), 59.78 years (2011 est.), 59.25 years (2006 est.) :Male: 60 years (2017 est.), 57.85 years (2011 est.), 57.7 years (2006 est.) :Female: 64.3 years (2017 est.), 61.77 years (2011 est.), 60.85 years (2006 est.) ===Median age=== :Total: 18.8 years :Male: 18 years :Female: 19.7 years (2017 est.) ===Population growth rate=== :2.39% (2017 est.). Country comparison to the world: 25th ===Birth rate=== :33.4 births/1,000 population (2017 est.). Country comparison to the world: 28th ===Death rate=== :8.1 deaths/1,000 population (2017 est.). Country comparison to the world: 90th ===Mother's mean age at first birth=== :21.5 years (median age at first birth among women 25-29 (2016 est.)) ===[[Dependency ratio]]s=== :Total: 85.4 :Youth: 79.8 :Elderly: 5.6 :[[Potential support ratio]]: 18 (2015 est.) ===Literacy=== Definition: age 15 and over can read and write :Total population: 57.7% :Male: 69.7% :Female: 46.6% (2015 est.) ===Urbanization=== :urban population: 47.2% of total population (2018) :rate of urbanization: 3.73% annual rate of change (2015-20 est.) ===Maternal mortality ratio=== :315 deaths/100,000 live births (2015 est.) ===Drinking water source=== ;improved: :total: 78.5% of population :urban: 92.9% of population :rural: 67.3% of population ;unimproved: :total: 21.5% of population :urban: 7.1% of population :rural: 32.7% of population (2015 est.) ===[[School life expectancy]] (primary to tertiary education)=== :total: 9 years :male: 9 years :female: 9 years (2015) ===Gender ratio=== :At birth: 1.03 male(s)/female :Under 15 years: 1.01 male(s)/female :15-64 years: 0.98 male(s)/female :65 years and over: 0.87 male(s)/females :Total population: 0.99 male(s)/female (2011 est.) ==Emigration== Senegal aforetime was a destination country for neighboring economic migrants, but in recent decades West African migrants more often use Senegal as a transit point to North Africa and also to illegally onward to Europe. The country also has been host to several thousand black Mauritanian refugees since they were expelled from Mauritania during the 1989 border conflict with Senegal. The country’s economic crisis in the 1970s stimulated emigration; departures accelerated from the 1990s. Destinations shifted from neighboring countries to [[Libya]] and [[Mauritania]], because of their booming oil industries, and to [[France]], [[Italy]] and [[Spain]]. ==See also== *[[Senegal]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Commonscat-inline|Demographics of Senegal}} {{Africa in topic|Demographics of}} {{Serer topics|state=collapsed}} {{Senegal year nav}} {{Senegal topics}} [[Category:Demographics of Senegal|Senegal]] [[Category:Senegalese society]] [[pt:Senegal#Demografia]]

{{redirect|Drive-by}} {{For|the album by the Rollins Band|Drive by Shooting}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} A '''drive-by shooting''' is a type of [[assault]] that usually involves the perpetrator firing a weapon from within a [[motor vehicle]] and then fleeing.<ref name="hutson"> {{cite journal | last1 = Hutson | first1 = H. Range | last2 = Anglin | first2 = Deirdre | last3 = Pratts | first3 = Michael J. Jr. | title = Adolescents and Children Injured or Killed in Drive-By Shootings in Los Angeles | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199402033300506 | date = 3 February 1994 | url = http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199402033300506 }}</ref> Such shootings are associated with [[gang violence]] in [[urban area]]s of the United States but also occur in other contexts and other countries. The tactic is also called simply a "drive-by".<ref name="drive-by-wkyc"> {{cite news | title = 3-year-old boy killed in drive-by shooting identified | newspaper = WKYC-TV | location = Cleveland, Ohio | date = 16 September 2015 | url = http://www.wkyc.com/story/news/local/cleveland/2015/09/16/3-year-old-child-woman-shot-cleveland/72343122/ | access-date = 11 December 2015}} </ref> The primary motivations for a gang-involved drive-by include intimidation, terrorization, and assassination of rival street gang members.<ref name="gang-epidemic"> {{cite journal | last1 = Hutson | first1 = H. Range | last2 = Anglin | first2 = Deirdre | last3 = Kyriacou | first3 = Demetrios N. | title = The Epidemic of Gang-Related Homicides in Los Angeles County From 1979 Through 1994 | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | doi = 10.1001/jama.1995.03530130037025 | date = 4 October 1995 | url = http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=389725 }}</ref> Drive-by shootings allow the perpetrator(s) to quickly strike their target and flee the scene before law enforcement is able to respond. The invention of drive by shooting is attributed to [[Nestor Makhno]]<ref>William Henry Chamberlin, ''Russia's Iron Age'', Ayer Publishing, 1970, p201; V. Rapoport, Y. Alekseev, V. G. Treml (translated by B. Adams)</ref><ref>''High Treason: Essays on the History of the Red Army, 1918-1938'', Duke University Press, 1985, p68</ref><ref>Michael Malet, ''Nestor Makhno in the Russian Civil War'', Macmillan, 1982, p85</ref><ref>Steve Zaloga, Leland S. Ness, ''Red Army Handbook, 1939-45'', Sutton, 1998, p105</ref><ref>Leon Trotsky, ''How the Revolution Armed: The Military Writings and Speeches of Leon Trotsky'', New Park Publications, 1981, p 295</ref><ref>Edward R. Kantowicz, The Rage of Nations: The World In The Twentieth Century, Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1999, p173</ref>, commander of the Revolutionary Insurrection Army of [[Ukraine]] at the beginning of the 20th century. He combined horse and [[carriage]] with a machine gun in order to quickly assault targets and get away before they could properly react.
Numerous [[hip hop]] artists have been targeted in drive-bys;<ref name="rappers">{{cite web | url = http://hiphopwired.com/2013/02/01/they-shootin-10-rappers-that-were-targeted-in-drive-by-shootings/ | title = They Shootin’: 10 Rappers That Were Targeted In Drive-By Shootings | last = Coleman | first= C. Vernon II | date = 1 February 2013 | website = HipHopWired | access-date = 11 December 2015 }} </ref> prominent rappers who were killed in such incidents include [[Tupac Shakur]],<ref name="pac">{{cite web | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/tupac-shakur-dies-days-drive-by-shooting-1996-article-1.749382 | title = Tupac Shakur dies days after drive-by shooting in 1996 | last = Dominguez | first = Robert | date = 14 September 1996 | website = New York Daily News | access-date = 11 December 2015 | quote = Rapper Tupac Shakur died yesterday from wounds suffered in a Las Vegas drive-by shooting, becoming a casualty of the kind of bullet-sprayed urban violence captured in his lyrics.}} </ref> [[The Notorious B.I.G.]],<ref name="biggie">{{cite web | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/biggie-smalls-killed-drive-by-shooting-1997-article-1.758357 | title = Biggie Smalls is killed in a drive-by shooting in 1997 | last = Millner | first = Denene | date = 10 March 1997 | website = New York Daily News | access-date = 11 December 2015 }} </ref> [[Big L]], Smoke Dawg, and [[Mac Dre]].<ref name="dre">{{cite web | url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/65810/rapper-mac-dre-killed-in-kansas-city | title = Rapper Mac Dre Killed In Kansas City | date = 2 November 2004 | website = Billboard.com | access-date = 11 December 2015 }} </ref>
==Usage== Motorcycle ride-by killings were a common form of murder used by drug lord [[Griselda Blanco]] during her years controlling the [[Miami]] cocaine trade routes in the late 1970s and early 1980s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Corben|first1=Billy|title=Griselda Blanco: So Long and Thanks for All the Cocaine|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/3b5jz8/griselda-blanco-so-long-and-thanks-for-all-the-cocaine|accessdate=24 July 2017|work=Vice|date=4 September 2012|language=en-us}}</ref> Blanco herself died by this method after having been shot twice in the head by a motorcyclist in a drive-by shooting in [[Medellín, Colombia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/04/godmother-cocaine-shot-dead-colombia |title='Godmother of cocaine' shot dead in Colombia |work=The Guardian |first=Richard |last=Luscombe |date=September 4, 2012 |accessdate=March 3, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/latest-news/article1942452.html#storylink=cpy|work=Miami Herald|date=September 5, 2012|title= The life and death of 'cocaine godmother' Griselda Blanco|author=Robles, Frances|author2=Bargent, James|last-author-amp=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/04/godmother-cocaine-shot-dead-colombia |title='Godmother of cocaine' shot dead in Colombia (Griselda Blanco, who remained under suspicion for the deaths of all three of her husbands) |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=September 4, 2012| author=Luscombe, Richard }}</ref> Drive-by shootings are also included in the [[Ku Klux Klan]]'s ''[[modus operandi]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fontaine|first1=Smokey|title=GOOD NEWS: Victim Of KKK and Drive-By Shooting Opens Successful Restaurant|url=https://newsone.com/241747/good-news-victim-of-kkk-and-drive-by-shooting-opens-successful-restaurant/|accessdate=15 June 2017|agency=NewsOne|date=2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-carson-drive-by-shooting-20160228-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|title=Mother and son are killed in a drive-by shooting outside a Carson home |author=Hamilton, Matt |date=February 28, 2016 }}</ref> and in the first decade of the 21st century, drive-by shootings were also used by militants in [[Iraq]], including the assassinations of [[Waldemar Milewicz]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3693389.stm |title=Top Baghdad official shot dead: Aftermath of attack on Baghdad deputy governor: Attackers rammed the deputy governor's car and shot him dead (Gunmen have assassinated the deputy governor of Baghdad and wounded two of his bodyguards, Iraqi officials say) |publisher=BBC News |date=7 May 2004 |accessdate=10 August 2012}}</ref> and [[Hatem Kamil]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3970619.stm |title=Polish TV crew attacked in Iraq: Waldemar Milewicz was a well-known war correspondent (Gunmen in Iraq have killed a leading Polish journalist and his picture editor in a drive-by shooting) |publisher=BBC News |date=1 November 2004 |accessdate=10 August 2012}}</ref> From the 1970s into the 21st century, the [[Camorra]] in [[Naples]], [[Italy]] have been known for performing drive-by shootings during clan or gang wars.<ref name="ambrose">{{cite book|last1=Ambrose|first1=Tom|title=The Nature of Despotism|date=2008|publisher=New Holland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OGDuAAAAMAAJ&q=drive+by+shootings+camorra&dq=drive+by+shootings+camorra&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiSyMSvmO3QAhVBLyYKHZDvDxUQ6AEIJjAC}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = From Russia with Love | image = From Russia with Love – UK cinema poster.jpg | border = yes | caption = British [[cinema poster]] for ''From Russia with Love'', designed and illustrated by [[Renato Fratini]] and [[Eric Pulford]] | alt = The upper centre of the poster reads "Meet James Bond, secret agent 007. His new incredible women ... His new incredible enemies ... His new incredible adventures ..." To the right is Bond holding a gun, to the left a montage of women, fights and an explosion. On the bottom of the poster are the credits. | starring = [[Sean Connery]]
[[Pedro Armendáriz]]

[[Robert Shaw (British actor)|Robert Shaw]]
