{{EngvarB|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[His Excellency]] | name = Varahagiri Venkata Giri | image = V.V.Giri.jpg | caption = V. V. Giri | office = [[List of Presidents of India|4th]] [[President of India]] | vicepresident = [[Gopal Swarup Pathak]] | term_start = 24 August 1969 | term_end = 24 August 1974 | predecessor = [[Mohammad Hidayatullah]] (Acting) | successor = [[Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed]] | primeminister2 = [[Indira Gandhi]] | term_start2 = 3 May 1969 | term_end2 = 20 July 1969 | predecessor2 = [[Zakir Hussain (politician)|Zakir Hussain]] | successor2 = [[Mohammad Hidayatullah]] (Acting) | primeminister3 = [[Indira Gandhi]] | office3 = 3rd [[Vice-President of India|Vice President of India]] | primeminister4 = [[Indira Gandhi]] | president3 = [[Zakir Hussain (politician)|Zakir Hussain]] | term_start3 = 13 May 1967 | term_end3 = 3 May 1969 | predecessor3 = [[Zakir Hussain (politician)|Zakir Hussain]] | successor3 = [[Gopal Swarup Pathak]] | office4 = [[List of Governors of Karnataka|Governor of Karnataka]] | 1blankname4 = Chief Minister | 1namedata4 = [[S. Nijalingappa]] | term_start4 = 2 April 1965 | term_end4 = 13 May 1967 | predecessor4 = [[Satyawant Mallannah Shrinagesh]] | successor4 = [[Gopal Swarup Pathak]] | office5 = [[List of Governors of Kerala|Governor of Kerala]] | 1blankname5 = Chief Minister | 1namedata5 = [[Pattom A. Thanu Pillai|Pattom Thanu Pillai]]
[[R. Sankar]] | term_start5 = 1 July 1960 | term_end5 = 2 April 1965 | predecessor5 = [[Burgula Ramakrishna Rao]] | successor5 = [[Ajit Prasad Jain]] | office6 = [[List of Governors of Uttar Pradesh|Governor of Uttar Pradesh]] | 1blankname6 = Chief Minister | 1namedata6 = [[Sampurnanand]] | term_start6 = 10 June 1956 | term_end6 = 30 June 1960 | predecessor6 = [[Kanhaiyalal Maneklal Munshi]] | successor6 = [[Burgula Ramakrishna Rao]] | office7 = [[Minister of Industry|Minister of Labour and Industry]] for [[Madras Presidency]] | 1blankname7 = Chief Minister | 1namedata7 = [[Tanguturi Prakasam]] | term_start7 = 30 April 1946 | term_end7 = 23 March 1947 | birth_name = Varahagiri Venkata Giri | birth_date = {{birth date|1894|8|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Berhampur]], [[Madras Presidency]], [[British Raj|British India]]
(now in [[Odisha]], [[India]]) | death_date = {{death date and age|1980|6|24|1894|8|10|df=y}} | death_place = [[Madras]], [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]]
(now [[Chennai]]) | party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] | spouse = Saraswati Bai (1904–1978) | relatives = *[[Adruti Laxmibai]] (sister){{cite web |author1=Dr Dasarathi Bhuyan |title=Participation of Women of Ganjam District in the Freedom Movement of India |url=http://magazines.odisha.gov.in/Orissareview/2010/August/engpdf/august%202010.pdf |publisher=Orissa Review |accessdate=27 November 2018 |pages=18–20 |format=PDF}} *[[Palagummi Sainath]] (grandson){{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/cockburn08042005.html |title=Why Indian Farmers Kill Themselves; Why Lange's Photographs are Phony |publisher=Counterpunch.org |date=4 August 2005 |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050807232632/http://www.counterpunch.org/cockburn08042005.html |archivedate=7 August 2005 |df= }}
| alma_mater = [[Khallikote College]]
[[University College Dublin]] | awards = [[Bharat Ratna]] (1975) | signature = Varahagiri Venkatagiri Signature.jpg | signature_alt = Varahagiri Venkatagiri Signature in English }} '''Varahagiri Venkata Giri''' {{audio|Vvg.ogg|pronunciation}} (10 August 1894 – 24 June 1980), commonly known as '''V. V. Giri''', was the [[List of Presidents of India|fourth]] [[president of India]] from 24 August 1969 to 24 August 1974. As president, Giri was the only person to be elected as an independent candidate.{{Cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/bjp-vs-opposition-india-set-to-witness-tightest-presidential-poll-since-1969/story-sZ5LlpWvMBaxPULLoQHZbN.html |title=NDA vs Oppn: India might to witness tightest presidential poll since 1969 |last=Chatterji |first=Saubhadra |date=2017-04-26 |website=[[Hindustan Times]] |language=en |access-date=2018-06-21}} He was succeeded by [[Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed]] as president in 1974.{{cite web | url=http://pib.nic.in/archieve/others/gal.html | title=Gallery of Indian Presidents |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212121818/http://pib.nic.in/archieve/others/gal.html |archive-date=2017-12-12 |website=[[Press Information Bureau]] |publisher=Government of India |access-date=2018-06-21 |df=dmy-all}} After the end of his full term, Giri was honoured by the [[Government of India]] with the [[Bharat Ratna]] in 1975. Giri died on 24 June 1980. His great grandson V. Giri Shankar is an Advocate of the Madras High Court, Chennai. ==Early life== Giri was born in [[Berhampur]], [[Odisha]] to a [[Telugu people|Telugu]] [[Niyogi Brahmin]] family. His father, V. V. Jogayya Pantulu, was a successful lawyer and political activist of the Indian National Congress.{{Cite book|title=The Great Indian Patriots, Volume 1|last=Rao|first=P. Rajeswar|publisher=Mittal Publications|year=1991|isbn=9788170992806|location=India|pages=279–282|quote=|via=Google Books}} Giri's mother Subhadramma was active in the national movement in Berhampur during the [[Non Cooperation Movement|Non Cooperation]] and [[Civil Disobedience Movement]]s and was arrested for leading a strike for [[prohibition]] during the Civil Disobedience Movement.{{cite journal|last1=Sarma|first1=Bina Kumari|title=Women’s Role in the Freedom Movement in South Orissa|journal=Orissa Review|date=August 2010|pages=34–35|url=http://orissa.gov.in/e-magazine/Orissareview/2010/August/engpdf/34-38.pdf|accessdate=8 February 2015}} Giri was married to Saraswati Bai and the couple had 14 children.{{cite book|author=P. Rajeswar Rao|title=The Great Indian Patriots|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eTrs9MF9374C&pg=PA278|year=1991|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-280-6|page=282}} Giri completed his initial education at the [[Khallikote College]], then affiliated with [[Utkal University]], in Berhampur.{{cite web|title=Varahagiri Venkata Giri|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/234218/Varahagiri-Venkata-Giri|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=8 February 2015}} In 1913 he went to Ireland to study law which he did at [[University College Dublin]] and the [[King's Inns|Honourable Society of King's Inns, Dublin]] between 1913–1916.{{cite news|title=University College Dublin announces special scholarships for Indian students|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/university-college-dublin-announces-special-scholarships-for-indian-students/1/328125.html|accessdate=8 January 2015|publisher=India Today|date=6 November 2013}} Giri was one among the first crop of thirteen Indian students who sat the obligatory year long course at UCD in 1914–15. This was a requirement for being called to the Irish Bar through study at the King's Inns. In total, 50 Indian students studied at UCD between 1914 and 1917.{{Cite book|title=Irish Days, Indian Memories: V. V. Giri and Indian Law Students at University College Dublin, 1913–1916|last=Mulvagh|first=Conor|publisher=Irish Academic Press|year=2016|isbn=978-1-911024-18-7|location=Sallins|pages=43|quote=|via=}} Giri and a fellow law student also enrolled to study on the full bachelor of arts course in UCD. Giri studied English, where he was lectured by [[Thomas MacDonagh]], and Political Economy. His lecturer in political economy was the reformer and co-operativist [[Thomas A. Finlay|Thomas A. Finlay SJ]]. During the First World War, Giri travelled from Dublin to London and met with [[Mahatma Gandhi]]. Gandhi wanted for Giri to join the Imperial war effort as a Red Cross Volunteer. Giri initially acceded to Gandhi's request but later regretted his decision. According to one of Giri's biographers, "Gandhiji with his characteristic magnanimity relieved Giri of the obligation to join the Red Cross and did not breathe a word about it to anyone.”{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/gandhi-an-expelled-future-president-and-first-aid-crews-the-indians-of-1916-rising-1.2529440|title=Gandhi, an expelled future president and first aid crews: the Indians of 1916 Rising|last=Mulvagh|first=Conor|date=10 February 2016|work=|newspaper=The Irish Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-17|via=}} Giri was active in both Indian and Irish politics during his studies. Along with fellow Indian students he produced a pamphlet documenting the abuse of Indians in South Africa. The pamphlet was intercepted by [[Indian Political Intelligence Office|Indian Political Intelligence]] and resulted in increased police scrutiny of Giri and his fellow students in Dublin. Meanwhile, anonymous articles were written by Indian students for the newspaper of the [[Irish Volunteers]] and in ''The National Student'', a UCD student magazine.{{Cite book|title=Irish Days, Indian Memories: V. V. Giri and Indian Law Students at University College Dublin, 1913–1916|last=Mulvagh|first=Conor|publisher=Irish Academic Press|year=2016 |isbn=978-1-911024-18-7|location=Sallins, Co. Kildare, Ireland|pages=34, 49–50|quote=|via=http://irishacademicpress.ie/product/irish-days-indian-memories-v-v-giri-and-indian-law-students-at-university-college-dublin-1913-1916/}} He was suspected of association with prominent ring leaders in the [[Easter Rising|1916 Rising]] including [[James Connolly]], [[Patrick Pearse|PH Pearse]] and the young [[Éamon de Valera]].{{cite news|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2005/08/04/why-indian-farmers-kill-themselves-why-lange-s-photographs-are-phony/|title=Why Indian Farmers Kill Themselves; Why Lange’s Photographs are Phony|date=25 March 2005|publisher=Counter Punch |last1=Cockburn |first1=Alexander|accessdate=19 January 2015}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iLxnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA636|title=NOTHING BUT!|date=December 2013|publisher=Author Solutions|isbn=978-1-4828-1626-6|pages=636–|author=Brigadier Samir Bhattacharya}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RwfKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1538|title=Heads of States and Governments Since 1945|date=4 February 2014|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-134-26497-1|pages=1538–|author=Harris M. Lentz}} Giri was called to the Irish Bar on 21 June 1916 but he did not complete his studies for BA in UCD. Indian students were subjected to police raids following the 1916 Rising and Giri recounts how he was served with one month's notice to leave Ireland on 1 June 1916.{{Cite web |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1916/jun/01/mr-t-a-chettiar-of-madras#S5CV0082P0_19160601_CWA_3|title=MR. T. A. CHETTIAR, OF MADRAS. (Hansard, 1 June 1916)|website=hansard.millbanksystems.com|access-date=2017-01-17}} ==Career== Upon returning to India in 1916 Giri enrolled at the [[Madras High Court]].{{cite news|title=Worker’s leader who turned President|url=http://archive.deccanherald.com/Deccanherald/aug082004/ac3.asp|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=The Deccan Herald|date=8 August 2004}} He also became a member of the Congress party, attended its [[Lucknow]] session and joined the [[Home Rule Movement]] of [[Annie Beasant]].{{cite book|author=Janak Raj Jai|title=Presidents of India, 1950–2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r2C2InxI0xAC&pg=PA76|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Regency Publications|isbn=978-81-87498-65-0|page=76}} Giri abandoned a flourishing legal career in response to [[Mahatma Gandhi|Mahatma Gandhi's]] call for a [[Non-Cooperation Movement]] in 1920.{{cite news|title=Shekhawat need not compare himself to Giri: Shashi Bhushan|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/shekhawat-need-not-compare-himself-to-giri-shashi-bhushan/article1871463.ece|accessdate=8 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=12 July 2007}} In 1922, he was arrested for the first time for demonstrating against the sale of liquor shops. === Role in the labour movement === Giri was closely associated with the labour and trade union movement in India throughout his career.{{cite book|last1=Shukla|first1=Chandrashanker|title=Reminiscences of Gandhiji|date=March 1951|publisher=Vora & Co.|location=Bombay|page=108 |url=http://krishikosh.egranth.ac.in/bitstream/1/20434/1/G-2493.pdf|accessdate=15 January 2015}} Giri was a founding member of the [[All India Railwaymen's Federation]] which was formed in 1923 and served as its general secretary for over a decade.{{cite web|title=President of India speaking!|url=http://www.taxindiaonline.com/RC2/inside2.php3?filename=bnews_detail.php3&newsid=5743|publisher=taxindiaonline.com|accessdate=8 February 2015}}{{cite book|author=S. Chandrasekhar|title=Dimensions of Socio-political Change in Mysore, 1918–40 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zqz9SbueWk4C&pg=PA113|year=1985|publisher=Ashish Publishing House|isbn=978-0-8364-1471-4|pages=113–}}{{cite news|title=A principled politician |url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2002/09/23/stories/2002092301370200.htm|accessdate=8 February 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=23 September 2002}} He was elected president of the [[All India Trade Union Congress]] for the first time in 1926.{{cite book|author=Surjit Mansingh|title=Historical Dictionary of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6HAeAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA240|date=9 May 2006|publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=978-0-8108-6502-0|pages=240–}} Giri also founded the Bengal Nagpur Railway Association and in 1928 led the workers of the [[Bengal Nagpur Railway]] in a non violent strike for the rights of [[Retrenchment|retrenched]] workers. The strike succeeded in forcing the [[British Raj|British Indian government]] and the management of the railway company to concede the workers' demands and is regarded as a milestone in the labour movement in India. In 1929, the Indian Trade Union Federation (ITUF) was formed by Giri, [[N. M. Joshi]] and others with Giri as the president. The split with the AITUC came about over the issue of cooperating with the Royal Commission on Labour. Giri and the ITUF leadership of liberals decided to cooperate with the Commission while the AITUC decided to boycott it.{{cite book|author=Mohammad Tarique|title=Modern Indian History |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pcKMD9XWyjAC&pg=SA7-PA2|publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill Education|isbn=978-0-07-066030-4|pages=7–}} The ITUF merged with the AITUC in 1939 and Giri became president of the AITUC for a second time in 1942.{{cite journal|last1=Bhowmik|first1=Sharit|title=The Labour Movement in India: Fractured Trade Unions and Vulnerable Workers|journal=Rethinking Development and Inequality|date=2013|volume=2|issue=Special Issue|page=86}}{{cite web|title=AITUC – Our Leaders|url=http://aituc.in/leaders.html|publisher=AITUC|accessdate=15 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206153013/http://aituc.in/leaders.html|archive-date=6 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Giri was the Workers' Delegate of the Indian delegation at the [[International Labour Conference]] of the [[ILO]] in 1927.{{cite book|title=List of Indian Delegates and Advisers to International Labour Conferences (1919–2011)|publisher=V.V.Giri National Labour Institute, Ministry of Labour & Employment|location=NOIDA|url=http://www.vvgnli.org/sites/default/files/publication_files/List-of-Indian-Delegates-Advisors.pdf|accessdate=15 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207151828/http://www.vvgnli.org/sites/default/files/publication_files/List-of-Indian-Delegates-Advisors.pdf|archivedate=7 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} At the [[Round Table Conferences (India)|Second Round Table Conference]], Giri was present as a representative of the industrial workers of India. Giri worked towards getting the trade unions to support the freedom movement in India and was twice president of the AITUC which was closely allied with the Indian National Congress.{{cite book|author=Janak Raj Jai|title=Presidents of India, 1950–2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r2C2InxI0xAC&pg=PA75|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Regency Publications|isbn=978-81-87498-65-0|pages=75–}} == Electoral career in British India == Giri became a member of the [[Imperial Legislative Assembly]] in 1934.Narasingha P. Sil, ''Giri, Varahagiri Venkata (1894–1980), trade unionist and president of India'' in ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'' (2004) He remained its member until 1937 and emerged a spokesman for matters of labour and trade unions in the Assembly. In the General Elections of 1936, Giri defeated the Raja of Bobbili to become a member of the [[Madras Legislative Assembly]]. Between 1937–1939, he was Minister for Labour and Industry in the Congress government headed by [[C Rajagopalachari]].{{cite book|author=Radhey Shyam Chaurasia|title=History of Modern India, 1707 A. D. to 2000 A. D|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MS_jrForJOoC&pg=PA300|date=1 January 2002 |publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Dist|isbn=978-81-269-0085-5|pages=300–}}{{cite book|author=Rajmohan Gandhi|title=Rajaji: A Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JjPHeRd7_UYC&pg=PA171|year=1997|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-026967-3|pages=171–}} Giri was appointed Governor of the National Planning Committee of the Indian National Congress in 1938. In 1939, the Congress ministries resigned in protest against the British decision to make India a party in the [[Second World War]]. Having returned to the labour movement, Giri was arrested and spent 15 months in prison till March 1941. Following the launch of the [[Quit India Movement]], Giri was imprisoned again by the colonial government in 1942.{{cite book|author1=Verinder Grover|author2=Ranjana Arora|title=Constitutional Schemes and Political Development in India: Towards Transfer of Power |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KBCd9ZKzbUUC&pg=PA8|date=1 January 1994|publisher=Deep & Deep Publications|isbn=978-81-7100-539-0|pages=8–}} He remained in prison when the AITUC met in [[Nagpur]] in 1943 where he was the president elect.{{cite book|author=Viv Bahadour Singh|title=Economic History of India: 1857–1956|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xeJEXFnGS6AC&pg=PA590|year=1981|publisher=Allied Publishers|pages=590–|id=GGKEY:24F385A0Y8G}}{{cite book|title=Economic History of India: 1857–1956|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xeJEXFnGS6AC&pg=PA590|publisher=Allied Publishers|pages=590–|id=GGKEY:24F385A0Y8G}} Giri served his sentence in the [[Vellore]] and [[Amravati|Amaravathi]] prisons.{{cite book|author=A. Ranga Reddy|title=The State of Rayalaseema |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_g9T8UoCeO4C&pg=PA373|year=2003|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-814-3|pages=373–}} Giri remained in prison for three years, his longest sentence, until his release in 1945. In the [[Madras legislative assembly election, 1946|General Elections of 1946]], Giri was reelected to the Madras Legislative Assembly and became a minister again in charge of the labour portfolio under [[T. Prakasam]]. == Career in independent India == From 1947 to 1951, Giri served as India's first High Commissioner to [[Ceylon]].{{cite news|title=Nirupama Rao presents credentials to Chandrika|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2004/09/18/stories/2004091807611300.htm|accessdate=8 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=18 September 2004}} In the [[General elections in India|General Elections of 1951]], he was elected to the [[1st Lok Sabha]] from [[Pathapatnam]] Lok Sabha Constituency in the [[Madras State]].{{cite book|title=Key Highlights of General Elections, 1951 to the First Lok Sabha|publisher=Election Commission of India|location=New Delhi|page=15|url=http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/SR_KeyHighLights/LS_1951/VOL_1_51_LS.PDF|accessdate=9 January 2015}} === Union Minister for Labour (1952–1954) === On being elected to Parliament, Giri was appointed Minister of Labour in 1952.{{cite book|author=Rohini Hensman|title=Workers, Unions, and Global Capitalism: Lessons from India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ruusCMIQw7EC&pg=PT75|date=20 August 2013|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-51956-4|pages=75–}} His policy initiatives as minister gave rise to the ''Giri Approach'' in industrial dispute resolution.{{cite journal|title=Labour Problems — The "Giri Approach "|journal=The Economic Weekly|date=13 September 1952|page=951|url=http://www.epw.in/system/files/pdf/1952_4/37/labour_problems__the_giri_approach.pdf|accessdate=9 January 2015}} The Giri approach emphasizes negotiations between the management and workers as the means for resolving industrial disputes. It holds that the failure of such negotiations should lead not to compulsory adjudication but to further negotiations through conciliation officers.{{cite book|author=Pravin Durai|title=Human Resource Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aan1hKH_ejUC&pg=PA392|publisher=Pearson Education India|isbn=978-81-317-6783-2|pages=392–}}{{cite book|author=N. B. Ghodke|title=Encyclopaedic Dictionary of Economics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4_1OU9cVM4YC&pg=PA522|year=1985|publisher=Mittal Publications|pages=522–|id=GGKEY:6QZ9XL35Q32}} However, differences with the government over patronage to trade unions, trade union and government opposition to the Giri Approach and the government's decision to reduce the wages of bank employees led him to resign from government in August 1954.{{cite book|author=Singh|title=Industrial Relations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gl0tzPYgko8C&pg=PA94|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Excel Books India|isbn=978-81-7446-619-8|pages=94–}}{{cite book|author=Manoranjan Mohanty|title=Class, Caste, Gender|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=msyGAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA117|date=6 May 2004|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-81-321-0369-1|pages=117–}}{{cite book|author=Shree Govind Mishra|title=Democracy in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cFs0YSkA4ckC&pg=PA301|year=2000|publisher=Sanbun Publishers|isbn=978-3-473-47305-2|pages=301–}} In the General Elections of 1957, Giri lost from the [[Parvathipuram (Lok Sabha constituency)|Parvatipuram]] double-member constituency.{{efn|In the General Elections of 1952 and 1957, 83 dual member constituencies electing a member each from the general population and the [[Scheduled Caste]] or [[Scheduled Tribes]] was established. The general candidates including Giri received fewer votes than the Scheduled Caste candidates in Parvatipuram resulting in both the Scheduled Caste candidates being declared elected. Giri unsuccessfully challenged the verdict in court. By the Two Member Constituency (Abolition) Act, 1961 this system of double member constituencies was abolished.{{cite news|title=Between Red And Blue|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/printarticle.aspx?280573|accessdate=15 January 2015|publisher=Outlook|date=16 April 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115114557/http://www.outlookindia.com/printarticle.aspx?280573|archive-date=15 January 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=Have you heard of 2 being elected from one seat? flashback|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/have-you-heard-of-2-being-elected-from-one-seat-flashback/article334429.ece|accessdate=14 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=18 March 2009}}}}{{cite news|title=dated March 20, 1957: V.V. Giri defeated|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-miscellaneous/dated-march-20-1957-vv-giri-defeated/article1812948.ece|accessdate=14 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=20 March 2007}} Giri played an important role in founding the Indian Society of Labour Economics (ISLE).{{cite web|title=THE INDIAN SOCIETY OF LABOUR ECONOMICS|url=http://crl.du.ac.in/Publication/E-Resources%20in%20Public%20Domain-Final/Economics/Economics%20India/Home%20%20The%20Indian%20Society%20of%20Labour%20Economics.htm|publisher=The Indian Society of Labour Economics|accessdate=9 January 2015}} In June 1957, he was appointed [[Governor of Uttar Pradesh]].{{cite news|title=dated June 11, 1957: Governor of UP|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-miscellaneous/dated-june-11-1957-governor-of-up/article1854545.ece|accessdate=14 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=11 June 2007}} === Gubernatorial tenures (1957–1967) === Between 1957–1967, Giri served as governor of [[Uttar Pradesh]] (1957–1960), [[Kerala]] (1960–1965) and [[Karnataka]] (1965–1967).[http://vicepresidentofindia.nic.in/giri.asp President of India] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210115524/http://vicepresidentofindia.nic.in/giri.asp |date=10 February 2009 }} ==== Governor of Kerala (1960–1965) ==== Giri was sworn in as the [[List of Governors of Kerala|second Governor of Kerala]] on 1 July 1960.{{cite news|title=R.S. Gavai is new Kerala Governor|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/rs-gavai-is-new-kerala-governor/article1285183.ece|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=27 June 2008}} As Governor, Giri's active voicing of Kerala's fiscal needs with the [[Planning Commission (India)|Planning Commission]] led to the state being allocated significantly more funds in the Third [[Five Year Plan (India)|Five Year Plan]].{{cite book|author=Sibranjan Chatterjee|title=Governor's Role in the Indian Constitution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8UQpnoasCDYC&pg=PA148|date=1 January 1992|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-325-4|pages=148–}} When defections from the ruling Congress Party reduced the government to a minority, Giri recommended the imposition of [[President's rule|President's Rule]] in Kerala after determining that an alternative government could not be formed.{{cite book|author=Meera Srivastava|title=Constitutional Crisis in the States in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DAroH5ZqPgsC&pg=PA53|year=1980|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|pages=53–|id=GGKEY:0BS5QYU7XF2}} A hung assembly resulted from the elections to the [[Kerala Legislative Assembly]] in 1965. Since no party had a majority and no alliances commanding a majority could be formed, Giri again recommended the dissolution of the assembly and the imposition of President's Rule in the state.{{cite book|author=Kishor Gandhi|title=India's Date with Destiny: Ranbir Singh Chowdhary : Felicitation Volume|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BlkAf8Pe4GwC&pg=PA65|year=2006|publisher=Allied Publishers|isbn=978-81-7764-932-1|pages=65–}} === Vice president (1967–1969) and acting president of India (1969) === Giri was elected the [[List of Vice-Presidents of India|third]] [[Vice President of India|vice president of India]] on 13 May 1967, a post he held for nearly two years till 3 May 1969.{{cite web|title=Chapter – 4 Presiding Officers of Rajya Sabha and other Parliamentary Functionaries|url=http://rajyasabha.nic.in/rsnew/rsat_work/chapter-4.pdf|publisher=Rajya Sabha|accessdate=8 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206014203/http://rajyasabha.nic.in/rsnew/rsat_work/chapter-4.pdf|archive-date=6 February 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Giri was the first vice president to not complete his full term in office on account of being elevated to the office of the president and was the third vice president to be elected to the presidency.{{cite news|title=Krishan Kant is first vice-president to die in office|url=http://m.rediff.com/news/2002/jul/27vp1.htm|accessdate=19 January 2015|publisher=Rediff.com|date=27 July 2002}} Following the death in office of President [[Zakir Hussain (politician)|Zakir Hussain]] on 3 May 1969, Giri was sworn in as acting president the same day.{{cite book|author=K. Natwar Singh|title=Walking With Lions: Tales From A Diplomatic Past|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecHjAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA13-IA4|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers India|isbn=978-93-5029-899-2|pages=13–}} Giri resigned from his post on 20 July 1969 to contest the presidential elections as an independent candidate.{{cite book|author=Sudarshan Bhatia|title=His Excellency President of India Pranab Mukherjee|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mtv3AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT59|date=4 March 2014|publisher=Diamond Pocket Books Pvt Ltd|isbn=978-93-5083-645-3|pages=59–}} Immediately before resigning, Giri, in his capacity as acting president, promulgated an ordinance that nationalised 14 banks and insurance companies.{{cite book|author1=Senior Lecturer in Politics Vernon Hewitt|author2=Vernon Hewitt|title=Political Mobilisation and Democracy in India: States of Emergency|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sh6yVyWM4pwC&pg=PA85|date=5 November 2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-09762-3|pages=85–}} He was succeeded as acting president by [[Mohammad Hidayatullah]], the [[Chief Justice of India]].{{efn|Following Giri's resignation, the offices of president and vice president became vacant, with the [[Constitution of India]] requiring the Chief Justice of India to act as president. Justice Hidayatullah served as acting president during July – August 1969. Elected vice president in 1979, he again served as acting president in October 1982. He is the only person in India to have served twice as acting president.{{cite book|author=A. P. Bhardwaj|title=Legal Awareness and Legal Reasoning for the CLAT and LLb Entrance Examinations, 4/e|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RchoBAAAQBAJ&pg=SL1-PA241|isbn=978-93-325-3732-3|pages=1–}}}}{{cite news|title=The twice Acting-President|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-in-school/the-twice-actingpresident/article3676405.ece|accessdate=19 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=24 July 2012}} === Presidential election of 1969 === The election of a new president became a contest between the Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]] and the old guard of the Congress Party known as the Syndicate.{{cite book|last1=McLeod|first1=John|title=The History of India|date=2002|publisher=Greenwood Press|page=149|url=https://www.questia.com/read/101360237/the-history-of-india|accessdate=8 January 2015|subscription=yes|via=[[Questia]]}} The [[All India Congress Committee]] decided to support [[Neelam Sanjiva Reddy]] as the presidential candidate, disregarding the [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister's]] opposition.{{cite news|last1=Malhotra|first1=Inder|title=A populist move, a party chasm|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/a-populist-move-a-party-chasm/99/|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=The Indian Express|date=23 December 2013}} Giri, who was vice president, resigned and decided to contest as an independent candidate. Prime Minister Gandhi then decided to support him, endorsing a "vote of conscience" that allowed Congress legislators to vote for Giri.{{cite book|author=Ramachandra Guha|title=India After Gandhi: The History of the World's Largest Democracy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8FKepYC6wzwC&pg=PA438|date=10 February 2011|publisher=Pan Macmillan|isbn=978-0-330-54020-9|pages=438–}} The election, held on 16 August 1969, witnessed a contest between Reddy, Giri and the opposition candidate [[C D Deshmukh]].{{cite book|author1=Stanley Kochanek|author2=Robert Hardgrave|title=India: Government and Politics in a Developing Nation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pSyRgcSQhuIC&pg=PT82|date=30 January 2007|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=0-495-00749-8|pages=82–}} In the closely fought election V V Giri emerged victorious, winning 48.01 per cent of the first preference votes and subsequently getting a majority on counting the second preference votes. In the final tally, Giri had 420,077 votes against the quota of 418,169 votes required to be elected president.{{cite news|title=Sanjiva Reddy only President elected unopposed|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3529044.ece|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=15 June 2012}}{{cite book|author=M V Pylee|title=An Introduction To The Constitution Of India, 5E|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zps_kbj-9nsC&pg=PA158|date=1 November 2009|publisher=Vikas Publishing House Pvt Ltd|isbn=978-81-259-1832-5|pages=158–}} Following Giri's election, an [[election petition]] was filed in the [[Supreme Court of India]] contesting its validity on the grounds of having used corrupt practices to influence voters. Giri, unusually for an incumbent president of India, chose to appear in person before the Court where he was examined as a witness. The Court ultimately dismissed the petition and upheld Giri's election as president.{{cite news|title=How VV Giri defended himself|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-how-vv-giri-defended-himself-1106843|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=DNA|date=29 June 2007}} == President of India == [[File:State Visits by V V Giri.png|right|thumb|As President of India Giri led 14 state visits to countries in [[South Asia|South]] and [[South East Asia]], the [[Soviet bloc]] and [[Africa]].]] Giri was sworn in as President of India on 24 August 1969 and held office till 24 August 1974 when he was succeeded by [[Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed]].{{cite web|title=Former Presidents |url=http://presidentofindia.nic.in/former-presidents.htm |publisher=The President of India |accessdate=17 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016060850/http://presidentofindia.nic.in/former-presidents.htm |archivedate=16 October 2014 |df= }} On his election, Giri became the only president to have also been an acting president and the only person to be elected president as an independent candidate. As president, Giri unquestioningly accepted Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's decision to sack the [[Charan Singh]] ministry in Uttar Pradesh and advised her to go in for early elections in 1971.{{cite news|title=Past Presidents: Waning power|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/office-of-the-president-a-glamorous-edifice-but-with-a-timorous-reserve-of-real-power/1/391902.html|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=India Today|date=18 October 2013}} The [[Ordinance (India)|ordinance]] abolishing [[Privy Purse in India|privy purses]] and privileges of the erstwhile rulers of [[Princely state|India's princely states]] was promulgated by Giri after the government's original amendment was defeated in the [[Rajya Sabha]].{{cite book|author=Blema Steinberg|title=Women in Power: The Personalities and Leadership Styles of Indira Gandhi, Golda Meir, and Margaret Thatcher|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n2R0OAYkcgMC&pg=PA33|date=1 January 2008|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-7502-8|pages=33–}} His advice to Prime Minister Gandhi against the appointement of [[A.N. Ray]] as the [[Chief Justice of India]] superseding three judges senior to him was ignored by her as was his warning that a crackdown on striking railwaymen would only exacerbate the situation.{{cite news|title=Emerging evidence|url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mag/2003/01/05/stories/2003010500540200.htm|accessdate=15 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=5 January 2003}}{{cite book|last1=Carras|first1=Mary|title=Indira Gandhi: In the Crucible of Leadership|date=1979|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston|page=172|url=https://www.questia.com/read/96271846/indira-gandhi-in-the-crucible-of-leadership|accessdate=15 January 2015|subscription=yes|via=[[Questia]]}} As president, Giri made 14 state visits to 22 countries in [[South Asia|South]] and [[South East Asia]], [[Europe]] and [[Africa]].{{cite web|title=DETAILS OF MEDIA PERSONS ACCOMPANYING THE PRESIDENT IN HIS/HER VISITS ABROAD SINCE 1947 TO 2012|url=http://rashtrapatisachivalaya.gov.in/media_abroad.pdf|publisher=The President's Secretariat|accessdate=5 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130817094728/http://rashtrapatisachivalaya.gov.in/media_abroad.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=President's visits undertaken after careful appraisal|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/presidents-visits-undertaken-after-careful-appraisal/article3255825.ece|accessdate=19 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=29 March 2012}} Giri is regarded as a president who completely subordinated himself to the prime minister and has been described as a "Prime Minister’s President",{{cite journal|title=Changing Roles of the Presidents of India|journal=Mainstream Weekly|date=17 August 2012|volume=L|url=http://www.mainstreamweekly.net/article3633.html|accessdate=17 January 2015}} a loyalist president and a [[Rubber stamp (politics)|rubber stamp]] president under whom the independence of the office eroded.{{cite book|author1=Abdo I. Baaklini|author2=Helen Desfosses|title=Designs for Democratic Stability: Studies in Viable Constitutionalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFhiXjPle1AC&pg=PA162|date=1 January 1997|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=978-0-7656-0052-3|pages=162–}}{{cite news|title=Pranab won’t be a ‘rubber stamp’|url=http://archive.asianage.com/india/pranab-won-t-be-rubber-stamp-935|accessdate=17 January 2015|publisher=The Asian Age|date=23 July 2012}}{{cite journal|last1=Noorani|first1=A G|title=The Parliamentary System in South Asia|journal=Criterion Quarterly|date=4 October 2013|volume=2|issue=3|url=http://www.criterion-quarterly.com/the-parliamentary-system-in-south-asia/|accessdate=2 February 2015}} When Giri's term ended in 1974, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi chose not to renominate him to the presidency and instead chose Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed, who was elected in the presidential election of 1974.{{cite book|author=Ananth|title=India Since Independence: Making Sense of Indian Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CBQ7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA84|isbn=978-81-317-4282-2|pages=84–}} == Bharat Ratna == Giri was honoured with India's highest civilian award, the [[Bharat Ratna]], in 1975 for his contributions in the area of public affairs.{{cite web|title=List of recipients of the Bharat Ratna|url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/Recipients-BR.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India|accessdate=17 January 2015}}{{cite news|title=List of all Bharat Ratna award winners|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/list-of-all-bharat-ratna-award-winners-81336|accessdate=17 January 2015|publisher=NDTV|date=24 January 2011}} As president, Giri had [[suo motu]] conferred the Bharat Ratna on Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1972.{{cite news|title=Awards earned, awards fixed?|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2003/01/19/stories/2003011900251600.htm|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=19 January 2003}} Giri was in turn conferred the Bharat Ratna in 1975 on the recommendation of Prime Minister Gandhi, in an act seen as a quid pro quo measure.{{cite news|title=Flashback to time of Nehru Ratna|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1141225/jsp/nation/story_5228.jsp#.VMPXQNKUe9p|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=The Telegraph|date=25 December 2014}}{{cite news|title=Bose or Vajpayee: India politicises, then downgrades Bharat Ratna|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/bose-or-vajpayee-india-politicises-then-downgrades-bharat-ratna-1659607.html|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=Firstpost|date=12 August 2014}}{{cite news|title=Bharat Ratna: It's not for 'useful citizens', it's for politicians and entertainers|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/bharat-ratna-it-s-not-for-useful-citizens-it-s-for-politicians-and-entertainers/article1-1303199.aspx|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=The Hindustan Times|date=4 January 2015}} Giri was the fourth of five of Presidents of India to have been conferred the Bharat Ratna.{{cite news|title=Awards and acrimony|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/opinion/columns/awards-and-acrimony/article5376264.ece|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu Businessline|date=21 November 2013}} == Death == Giri died of a [[heart attack]] in [[Madras]] on 24 June 1980.{{cite book|last=Lentz|first=Harris M.|title=Heads of States and Governments Since 1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D6HKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA379|accessdate=2018-06-21|date=2014-02-04|publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781134264902|pages=379–380}} He was given a [[state funeral]] the next day and a week-long mourning period was declared by the [[Government of India]].{{cite book|author=M.V. Kamath|title=Journalist's Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7A90vWbKyDEC&pg=PA222 |date=1 November 2009|publisher=Vikas Publishing House Pvt Ltd|isbn=978-0-7069-9026-3|pages=222–}} Rajya Sabha, of which Giri had been ex-officio chairman as Vice President of India, adjourned for two days as a mark of respect to him.{{cite book|title=Rajya Sabha at Work – Chapter 16: Obituary and Other References|page=386|url=http://rajyasabha.nic.in/rsnew/rsat_work/chapter-16.pdf|accessdate=6 January 2015|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123165001/http://rajyasabha.nic.in/rsnew/rsat_work/chapter-16.pdf|archivedate=23 November 2015|df=dmy-all}} == Commemoration == A [[commemorative postage stamp]] on V.V Giri was released by the [[India Posts|Indian Posts and Telegraphs Department]] in 1974.{{cite web|title=Postal Stamp Name : V V Giri|url=http://www.indianpost.com/viewstamp.php/Alpha/V/V.%20V.%20GIRI%20(PRESIDENT%20OF%20INDIA)|publisher=IndianPost|accessdate=9 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Stamps 1974|url=http://iic.ac.in/projects/nic/Contrivers/1974.html|publisher=Philately World|accessdate=9 January 2015}} The [[V. V. Giri National Labour Institute|National Labour Institute]] was renamed in honour of V.V Giri in 1995.{{cite web|title=V. V. Giri National Labour Institute: History|url=http://www.vvgnli.org/institute/history|publisher=VV Giri National Labour Institute|accessdate=9 January 2015}} Giri's hometown of Berhampur has a major road, a secondary training school and a market that are named after him.{{cite news|title=156-year-old school renamed after V. V. Giri|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/156yearold-school-renamed-after-v-v-giri/article3382923.ece|accessdate=9 January 2015|publisher=The Hindu|date=4 May 2012}} Giri authored ''Industrial Relations'' and ''Labour Problems in Indian Industry'', two popular books on issues of labour in India.{{cite book|author=Pravin Durai|title=Human Resource Management: For VTU|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EWQ8BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA387|isbn=978-81-317-9873-7|pages=387–}} His memoirs, published in 1976, are titled ''My Life and Times''.{{cite book|last1=Giri|first1=V V|title=My Life and Times, Volume 1|date=1976|publisher=Macmillan Company of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=blEKkgEACAAJ|accessdate=9 January 2015|isbn=9780333901335}} == Honours == * [[File:25th Anniversary Medal 1971.gif|50px]] Commemorative Medal of the [[2,500 year celebration of the Persian Empire|2500th Anniversary of the founding of the Persian Empire]] (14/10/1971)[http://badraie.com/guests.htm Badraie] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305043732/http://badraie.com/guests.htm |date=5 March 2016 }} * [[File:King Jigme Singye Investiture Medal 1974.gif|50px]] King Jigme Singye Investiture Medal (Kingdom of Bhutan, 02/06/1974)[http://archiv.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/savifadok/315/1/Coronation.pdf Final Programmes for The Coronation and The Silver Jubilee Celebration] * [[File:Bharat Ratna Ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Bharat Ratna]] (Republic of India, 1975) == Explanatory notes == {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|V. V. Giri}} {{Wikiquote}} * [https://www.britannica.com/biography/Varahagiri-Venkata-Giri V. V. Giri] at Encyclopædia Britannica {{Presidents of India}} {{IndianVicePresidents}} {{Governors of Uttar Pradesh}} {{Bharat Ratna}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Giri, V. V.}} [[Category:1894 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of University College Dublin]] [[Category:Governors of Karnataka]] [[Category:Governors of Kerala]] [[Category:Governors of Uttar Pradesh]] [[Category:Members of Central Legislative Assembly of India]] [[Category:Presidents of India]] [[Category:People from Ganjam district]] [[Category:Recipients of the Bharat Ratna]] [[Category:Vice-Presidents of India]] [[Category:Tamil Nadu ministers]] [[Category:Telugu people]] [[Category:Telugu politicians]] [[Category:Indian Hindus]] [[Category:Acting Presidents of India]] [[Category:University of Madras alumni]] [[Category:Labour ministers of India]] [[Category:1st Lok Sabha members]]

revision.text:
'''Virginia Durr Moment''' is a phrase originating in developmental psychology which refers to an experience and "triggering event" which can foster the moral development of an individual. Characteristic of the experience is a serious '''challenge''' to an individual's value system. The book [[Some Do Care]] by developmental psychologists [[William Damon]] and [[Anne Colby]] (who are husband and wife), use the experience of [[Virginia Foster Durr]] to describe this phenomenon. Although Durr is known as a civil rights activist, in her early years she harbored racial prejudice—a result of her upbringing in the South. When Durr was a student at [[Wellesley College]], her prejudiced value system was first seriously challenged.<ref name="Durr">{{cite web | title = Virginia Foster Durr Biography | publisher = | author = | date = | url = http://www.teacherlink.usu.edu/tlresources/reference/champions/pdf/VirginiaFosterDurr.pdf | accessdate = 2007-01-17 }}</ref> On her first night at Wellesley, Durr refused to dine at the same table at which a Negro girl was sitting. The head of the house explained that the rules of [[Wellesley College]] required Durr to dine with the girl for one month, and that if Durr did not comply, she would have to withdraw from the college. As Damon and Colby explain "this was the first time Virginia's values had ever been seriously challenged and she stayed awake all night long worrying about the dilemma". They later go on to quote Durr "That was the first time I became aware that my attitude was considered foolish by some people and that Wellesley College wasn't going to stand for it. That experience had a tremendous effect on me." (pg, 99, Some Do Care). The book [[Educating Citizens]]: Preparing America's Undergraduates for Lives of Moral and Civic Responsibility, also describes the developmental significance of Durr's challenge from Wellesley: "[T]he incident lodged in Virginia's memory, creat[ed] a fracture in her convictions about race that contributed to their later destruction" (pg. 3 Educating Citizens).
A '''Virginia Durr Moment''' refers to those experiences which—when used correctly—foster moral development. A '''Virginia Durr Moment''' presents one with the opportunity for growth via the evolution of one's value system via seriously challenging one's value system in a manner which causes one to reflect on and, as a result of this reflection, reject it in whole or in part. When used correctly, the signature causal sequence of a '''Virginia Durr Moment''' consists in: serious challenge-->self-reflection-->modification of value system-->moral development. Ultimately, it is up to the individual to use the Moment to promote growth and further his/her moral development. In the [[United Kingdom]], some circles understand [[Paul McCartney]]'s [[Blackbird (Beatles song)|Blackbird]] as describing the moral development fostered by the '''proper''' usage of a '''Virginia Durr Moment'''. An individual may experience a '''Virginia Durr Moment''' and fail to use its power, thereby remaining in a condition of developmental stasis and moral immaturity.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *''Some Do Care: Contemporary Lives of Moral Commitment'' by Anne Colby and William Damon (1992; New York: Free Press). {{ISBN|0029063566}} *''Outside the Magic Circle: The Autobiography of Virginia Foster Durr,'' edited by Hollinger F. Barnard (1985; New York: Simon & Schuster/Touchstone, 1987). {{ISBN|0-671-63855-6}} *''Educating Citizens: Preparing America's Undergraduates for Lives of Moral and Civic Responsibility,'' by Anne Colby, Thomas Ehrlic, Elizabeth Beaumont and Jason Stephens (2003; San Francisco: Josey-Bass/Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching). {{ISBN|0-7879-6515-4}} ==External links== * Oral History Interviews with Virginia Foster Durr [http://docsouth.unc.edu/sohp/G-0023-1/menu.html], [http://docsouth.unc.edu/sohp/G-0023-2/menu.html], [http://docsouth.unc.edu/sohp/G-0023-3/menu.html], [http://docsouth.unc.edu/sohp/A-0337/] from [http://docsouth.unc.edu/sohp/ Oral Histories of the American South]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Virginia Durr Moment}} [[Category:Developmental psychology]] [[Category:Behavioural sciences]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Ajtte entré.JPG|thumb|Entrance of Ájtte]] [[Image:Ajtte utställningshall.JPG|thumb|Permanent exhibition on the life of Sami nomads]] [[Image:Naturdiorama Ajtte.JPG|thumb|Diorama]] [[Image:Förrådsbod Ajtte på Ajtte.JPG|thumb|A storage hut (ájtte in the Lule Sami language) in front of the museum]] '''Ájtte''', the Swedish Mountain and Sami Museum ({{lang-sv|Svenskt fjäll- och samemuseum}}), is a cultural and natural history museum in [[Jokkmokk]] in [[Lapland (Sweden)|Lapland]], [[Sweden]].
Ájtte is a museum, which specializes in the culture and nature of the mountainous area of Northern Sweden, and which is also the main museum and archive for the [[Sami culture]] of Sweden. Ájtte is also an information centre for tourism in Lapland. The word ''ájtte'' is a [[Lule Sami language]] one, meaning storage hut and referring to the museum as an archive for artifacts of the Sami cultural heritage.
Ájtte was inaugurated in June 1989 and has a staff of about 25 employees. The museum is owned and managed by a foundation, which was established in 1983 by the Swedish Government, the Norrbotten Region, the [[Jokkmokk Municipality]] and the two national Sami organizations Svenska Samernas Riksförbund (National Union of Swedish Sami people) and Same Ätnam (Sami land). According to an agreement on financing of the museum, which was entered into the same year, the Government bodies commit themselves to a long term financial contribution to the museum. Such funds are the result of a court decision regarding compensation after rivers in Lapland have been exploited for electric power generation. The Swedish government appoints the chairman and three of the members of the board of the foundation. Thus, government funds cover around half of the current budget of the museum.<ref> Enquiry into the coordination of museums in Sweden, SOU 2009:15, page 144</ref>
==Jokkmokk Alpine Garden== Since 1995 Ájtte has established an alpine botanical garden at the valley of Kvarnbäcken in Jokkmokk with plants from different environments of the mountain range of Northern Scandinavia. One of the century old researcher cottages from [[Sarek National Park]], designed and used by the pioneering scientist [[Axel Hamberg]], has been dismantled and moved from Sarek and reerected in the botanical garden.
